This new regulation is under the "Possession and Use of Bait" section of the regulation so I can't see how it would preclude you from disposing of 'offal' into the lake as it was done in the past.
I wonder then if I'm no longer allowed to change out the water from my minnow container? Usually every couple hours you should dump the water out and then put fresh water in.

Somewhere in those new regs I'm sure I saw something that noted it was okay to change water for livewells, which is pretty much the same as a minnow bucket. Found it: (3) Paragraph 1( does not apply to water that is taken from the waters where the person is fishing, used in either a recirculating device attached to or forming part of a fishing vessel or a moveable container holding bait or baitfish, and deposited back into the same waters or within 30 m of those waters.
Makes sense. SeemsÂ like more rules for everyone to be confused about and misinterpret. Lol

Reference is made to "fish parts" so regardless of the title or section to which this stupid new rule belongs, it seems to indicate that dumping fish guts is now illegal.Â  Hopefully we will see intelligent enforcement of this.................

28Â (1)Â No person shall release or deposit, or attempt to release or deposit, into any waters, or within 30 m of any waters, any of the following: (a)Â live or dead bait or baitfish, including fish eggs, gametes or parts; or (b)Â the water, soil or other materials in the container used to hold the materials set out in paragraph (a). (2)Â Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of plant-based bait. (3)Â Paragraph 1(b) does not apply to water that is taken from the waters where the person is fishing, used in either a recirculating device attached to or forming part of a fishing vessel or a moveable container holding bait or baitfish, and deposited back into the same waters or within 30Â m of those waters. As G. Mech states this section only refers to baitfish.Â  There is no reference to your catch

28Â (1)Â No person shall release or deposit, or attempt to release or deposit, into any waters, or within 30 m of any waters, any of the following: (a)Â live or dead bait or baitfish, including fish eggs, gametes or parts; or (b)Â the water, soil or other materials in the container used to hold the materials set out in paragraph (a). (2)Â Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of plant-based bait. (3)Â Paragraph 1(b) does not apply to water that is taken from the waters where the person is fishing, used in either a recirculating device attached to or forming part of a fishing vessel or a moveable container holding bait or baitfish, and deposited back into the same waters or within 30Â m of those waters. THANKS!  	Evidently, the OOD article is in error when it said "fish parts" (see original post).Â  This is indeed good news. Doug
No dumping fish parts, we have just gone to bi weekly garbage pickup, should be able to crawl to the curb by itself by then.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral_hemorrhagic_septicemia " VHSV can be spread from fish to fish through water transfer, as well as through contaminated eggs,[3] and bait fish from infected waters.[41] The emerald shiner is a particularly popular bait fish in the Great Lakes region, and is among the species afflicted.[42] Survivors of the disease can become lifelong carriers of the virus, contaminating water with urine, sperm, and ovarian fluids.[1] The virus has been shown to survive two freeze/thaw cycles in a conventional freezer, suggesting both live and frozen bait could be a transmission vector. In Europe, the gray heron has spread the virus, but it does so mechanically; the virus is apparently inactive in the digestive tract of birds.[2] " They may be trying to prevent the spread of this? If the virus can survive 2 freeze thaw cycles in a conventional freezer? In pictures here of Lake Erie fish die offs there always seems to be Emerald Shiners in the pics, better not to use fish or parts for chum?
Seems like you can't kill that stuff.

You missed the part that this new law has to do with BAITFISH and not roe.Â Â Â No need to muddy the water with your statement.

From OOD, page 22. From OOD page 22. 	Chumming for fish Chumming is a common practice among anglers and refers to baiting an area to attract fish. However, thereâ€™s been longstanding confusion between chumming and regulations associated with bait-bucket dumping. For this reason, included in the 2019 proposal for multiple lines, the MNRF also sought input on clarifying these rules.At the time, the OFAH expressed concerns that the wording provided in the fishing regulations on bait bucket dumping was confusing and needed to be updated, and that the definition of bait for the purposes of chumming should be clearly defined and exclude risky baits (e.g. live or dead fish, bait-fish, leeches, frogs, crayfish, and roe. 	THE OPENER OFAH INSIDER 	It is now illegal to release or attempt to release live or dead bait or baitfish, including fish eggs, gametes or fish parts, the water, soil, or other materials used to hold any of these items into or within 30 metres of any water. These rules apply to all FMZs across Ontario. 	Chumming is still allowed, but only with plant-based baits or artificial corn.
Is this effective immediately? Wow
Regulations are current to 2021-01-28 and last amended on 2020-12-16 https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/sor-2007-237/page-3.html

Drop a can of corn with punched holes in it at the mouth of the Notty for whities and splake. Oh those were some good fishing days.

If it is true that fish guts can't be disposed of in the water body from which the fish came, that's another nail in the coffin for our outfitters who have already taken a crap-kicking with all the covid closures.Â  Let's say you have a small resort, maybe half a dozen cabins that are rented by the week to anglers, some of whom catch and keep fish to EAT and to take some home.Â  Right now the fish guts all go back into the lake, perfectly harmless.Â  If the outfitter has to remove the fish guts by burying them, taking them to a landfill, etc etc that is just one more cost that eats away at the bottom line for those folks who are already getting boned.Â  DUMB DUMB DUMB.Â  One size does NOT fit all........... Doug

Ya, I'm sure there's some good intent of not introducing species in some lakes, ie, pike into a lake of bass and walleye(Mountain Lake) Doug knows what I mean.Â  Or inadvertently dumping gobies or smelt into another non infested body of water. I know for a fact, somebody unaware of the consequences threw some minnows in the local Rod & Gun pond (Catawampus), 2 years later the annual kids trout derby was pretty dismal.Â  One of the guys pulled a 12lb pike out of the pond.Â  I don't have a problem using mashed up dead minnows, unlikely that would do any harm.Â  At the campground we used to dump the salmon and laker guts in the lake and watch crayfish clean that up.Â Â  One of the outfitters up north bagged all the walleye guts and had an old freezer out back of the cleaning hut and would take them to the dump every week.Â  Oh well.
